While it is true that ideas that fall out of fashion can be difficult to revive, it is not impossible. History has shown that ideas can have a cyclical nature, and can gain renewed attention and prominence in response to changing social, political, and economic contexts.

For example, the idea of socialism, which was once seen as politically and economically unfeasible, has experienced a resurgence in recent years with the growing frustration with economic inequality and corporate power. Similarly, the idea of civic engagement and the common good, once deemed outdated in the era of neoliberalism and privatization, has seen renewed interest in response to the growing recognition of social and environmental crises.

Moreover, as new problems and challenges arise, societies may turn to ideas and concepts from the past for inspiration and guidance. For example, the renewed interest in civic humanism, with its emphasis on civic virtue and engagement, has been driven in part by the recognition of the potential of collective action in addressing contemporary problems such as climate change and social inequality.

Overall, while it can be challenging to revive older, less popular ideas, it is possible for them to gain renewed attention and relevance in response to changing circumstances and evolving social and political contexts.
